text: Black with big head. Aroma is hops and malt. Taste is malt, syrupy, hops at end. Nice beer

From a bottle. Pours almost back with a thin tan head, so many big flavours in there; hops galore, coffee, chocolate and roasted bitter flavours. Smooth mouth feel with a hint of alcohol. Great beer if you love big strong flavours and high alcohol. Luckily I do.

On tap at Joe Canals West Deptford.
Appearance: Pitch black body with a tall and dense khaki head that very slowly dissipates. 
Aroma: The aroma reminds me of an aged American barleywine. The whole musky-ish orange/grapefruit thats in a musky basement aroma. Theres a backing of chocolate with a hint of pine and perhaps smoke which Im enjoying. I just dont like the hop choice.
Taste: The hoppiness is rather big and semi-aggressive, but so is the malt base. I get a big grapefruit bite with mild pine backed by big chocolate malts, a hint of roasted malts, and light smoke and licorice on the finish. Great black IPA.
Palate: Full-bodied, slightly syrupy, with mild carbonation.
Overall: This is a top notch black IPA, on par with Wookey Jack. I think I prefer Wookey Jack, but this is damn good. I with the hop profile leaned more towards the piney flavors and I wish that there wasnt hints of licorice, but even so this is great.

On tap at Barrels & Bottles. Brown/black with a lingering tan head and light lacing. Aroma of chocolate, sweet malts, earthy hops and caramel. Porter/Stout-like pour, nice beige-brown head, smells of roast, possible chocolate. Taste same roasty flavor, good body, with a hop bitter hit at the end.
Big, black, and hoppy as fuck. This is a thick one and definitely deserves to be drank a bit warmer. Get it!
(Backlog) The look is black, has a tan head and dark. The smell is hoppy, roast, citrus, and pine trees. You can almost chew the hops, a real mix of hops and roast in the taste.

Pours an espresso brown-black with a bit of tan head. Nice roasty, stout-like aroma. Roasty stout-lke flavor up front followed by a strong hoppy character and chased with some slight alcohol notes...finish is chocolatey-roasty.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2015 Tap: Deep, dark, woody brown but not quite fully black. Complete with ruby highlights & a quickly fading, khaki colored head. Black pour with a thin foamy laceful beige head. Nose is wonderful with aromas of roasted coffee and slightly bitter black malt, and a touch of pine. Not aggressive and nicely balanced and complex. Bitter where it needs to be, with appropriate roast and black sweetness.
Pitch black in the glass. A good sized head. That maybe should hold some longer, but OK. Roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. A bit simple. Long earthy dry bitterness at the aftertaste.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color ale with a nice dark brown foamy head with medium retention and not much lacing. Aroma consists of bitter roasted malt with some dry hoppy notes. Taste is also dominated by bitter roasted malt with quit a powerful dry hoppy finish. Body is about average with good carbonation. I thought this was a bit too dry IMHO.

My Bottom Line:
Starkly coniferous, this Imperial Black IPA also possesses fruity angles which expand into floral spikes, as toasted bread crumbs ground moderate bitterness. Expressive, to say the least.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam covers the brown-edged black.
-The mouthfeel is rich yet soft.
-The hoppiness is brutal, but very flavorful and exactly as advertised.
-You have to be in the mood for intensity here, but when you are, its going to be satisfying.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 6/20/2013. Pours pitch black color with a 1-2 finger dense tan head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, orange rind, cocoa, dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, light char, toast, floral, pine, and floral/roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus hops and roasted malt notes; with nice strength. Taste of big tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, orange rind, cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, char, floral, pine, toast, and floral/roasted earthiness. Good amount of roast/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus, citrus zest, cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, char, floral, pine, toast, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic balance and complexity of hop and roasted malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a creamy, chalky, and moderately sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming present after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent black IPA! All around great balance and complexity of hop and roasted malt flavors with huge robustness; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.
Bomber. Near black with a dark beige head. Dark malt, sugar and mild hops. Some chocolate.

Je verse une bière qui nest pas tout à fait noire dans mon grand verre de Shrek. Subitement, la mousse qui prend forme se déforme. On dirait quune dentelle arrive à saccrocher. Je plonge mon nez dans cette marée ténébreuse. Je sens du chocolat, des houblons américains, des épinettes et le parfum Acqua di Gioia de Giorgio Armani. Je porte le gobelet à mes lèvres. Je suis rapidement malmené par des houblons bien carabinés.  Le pamplemousse me vient en tête. La résine me colle entre les dents. Les malts noirs font ce quils peuvent et le font très bien. Jai un goût de gin Ungava qui me trotte sur les papilles. Mon palais surprend un corps plutôt léger. La texture huileuse ne souffre daucun complexe. Le pétillement juste mérite une attention. La finale est amère. Je ne sais plus comment ne plus aimer les choses brutalement longues et incendiaires.

Excellent representation of the Black IPA Style, and a double at that. Very smooth, with a nice hop finish. Way to go Clown Shoes and congratulations on your first year.. Its my favorite style, and this is one of the best!

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate chocolate, lighter caramel, grapefruit/citrus hops, light roast, and a touch of pine. It pours a dark black with no transparency and a one finger tan head that has decent retention and leaves a good amount of thin webbing and rings on the sides of the glass. The flavor starts with a quick dose of chocolate, roast, and a touch of caramel. The finish has a lot of citrus/grapefruit hops that dominate the little bit of pine that is there. While I wouldnt say you can taste any alcohol or feel any warmth, it does feel/taste "big.". As it warms, the hops fade considerably in the nose and only slightly in the flavor. Its medium bodied with soft carbonation and a somewhat sticky mouthfeel. Overall, its probably the hoppiest Black IPA Ive had. I normally have expectations that a Black IPA is more than likely going to taste like hoppy Porter. However, in this instance, Im buying into the concept that this is actually a Double Black IPA.

Bottle from De Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Shared with Nick. Deep dark brown pour with a lingering tan head. Gorgeous hoppy snout. From nose, to mouthfeel, to flavor. I really like this one.

Bottle thanks to a trade. Pours a clear dark brown with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of roasted malts with bitter pine hops and a hint of grapefruit. Flavor has strong bitter pine hops and resin throughout with a bit of roasted malt growing through the finish.

Bottle shared by derek. Pours near black with a creamy head that dissipated leaving a soapy film. Nose is loads of bitter chocolatey malts with a faint touch of vanilla. Taste is similar- the bitterness cutting any malt sweetness. Enjoyable straight forward beer.

Small beige head, rather stable, over red-brown shot, black beer. Woody, bar, solvent and resiny-hoppy, parsley. Very bitter, quinine-like, with a milder finish, featuring roast, scorched brown sugar, (bitter) spiced. Black chocolate, bit resin (if less than aromawise). Pepper, bitter leaves as from chicory. Medium to well-bodied, well-carbonated, hopoily-slick. Good, but it does appears a tad forced.

Bottle. Pours black as a politicians moral sense with a high, cratered, cinnamon head. Nose is dark fruit and roast, but with a gin-like herbal overtone; intriguing. It is as intense as advertised; a frontal punch of espresso and resiny notes offset by creamy date and fig, followed by a long, smooth, cafe au lait finish. Stays in balance the entire time, which impresses the heck out of me. Extreme it may be, but its also well made and very enjoyable.

Pours opaque black colour with beige head that disappears rather quickly. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, pine. Taste is sweet malts and turns into a hoppy bitter sensation, some dark fruits, roasty,  there is some slight alcohol in the taste as well. Medium carbonation, medium to full body. Dry bitter finish.
(bottle 15/06-2013) [10%] low beige head, black color, roasted very hoppy aroma, long hoppy taste, roasted chocolate taste, still a lot of hop aroma and taste. Bottled date 12/2011.

Very grassy hop aromas out of the bottle followed by some roasted malt.  Very dark brown with a light brown head.   Wow, this is everything it says it is.  Double: strong alcohol presence.   Black:  near black with a stout/porter-like darkness in color and flavor.  IPA:   Lots of hops here and they are all over the place and delicious!  Its hard to tell whats stinging your tongue, the alcohol or the hops.  The hops get a bit earthier (although it might be the mellowing effect of the dark malt), but the bitterness just keeps coming with pine and grapefruit notes.  Its balanced by smooth, sweet molasses and dark caramel.   Theres also an underlying coffee component thats really nice.  All of this coats the tongue so heavily that you taste the beer long after its gone and the next sip just reinforces whats already there.   Crazy, big, hoppy and delicious!
Bottle shared by Dogbrick on Memorial Day. Clear dark brown in color with a huge tan head. Malt and chocolate nose with some roast and hop. Malt and chocolate flavor with a grassy hop finish.

This ones for Walt.
Pours very dark brown with rich garnet highlights.
Roast malt aroma with lots of hops coming through.
Full flavor, some sweetness, some bitterness, both in a good balance.
Some slick licorice in the finish from the roast malts.
Nice beer.

650ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a smallish beige head, which does not last all that well, but does leave reasonable lacing. Roasty malt and toasted oat notes mix with resin and herbal hops in the aroma. Lemon, grapefruit and mandarin hops provide a strong citrus feel up front, before giving way to dark, roasty malt and black coffee in the mid-palate. Resin hops mix with coffee in the finish. A nice black IPA.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2015 Bottle share. The deepest blackish brown. Aroma is plum, vanilla, chocolate. Taste is roasted dark chocolate, raisin, and wood.

Dark ruby brown with small soapy beige head. Aroma is chocolate, hoppy, fruity, light roast, sweet - very nice. Flavor follows nose. Medium to full body. I think 2.0 is more like it. Has some barley wine like quality. Big Hop with accompanying piney bitterness. Roasty sweet. BIG. Some booze. Vinous. Sorta Jekyll and Hyde but overall enjoyable. Great beer to share with someone ;)

Smells very sweet. Chocolate, dark fruit, roasted malts, plus some lighter hops.  Very bold, yet smooth beer. Malt, hops, roast, chocolate, fruit. A very slight bitter aftertaste, but very sweet at the same time. Delicious.

This is night one of my Black DIPA tasting. This black DIPA is an instant fav. It's packed with strong hops and classic bitter DIPA qualities; however, the finish has a twinge of spicy cocoa.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone so go have a DIPA!

To me, this pours like a porter, taste like a stout, and has a hint of hops. Despite the math, the hops really loses in this battle. The dark and toasty malt is quite tasty, but I sure miss the hops I expected to find. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with medium yellow white head
Aromas of chocolate malts, tropical hoppy fruits, caramel, 
Nice bitterness from chocolate and dark malts. Slightly hoppy with grass, pine, resin and citrusy tones. Nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I should have asked about this as Im not a big black IPA fan. This one avoided nmy #1 problem w/ this style, a clash of hop flavor and roasted malts; unfortunately, the clash was avoided b having little hop flavor to clash with. Strong roasted smell with a little resin & caramel on the side. very light on the palate. Flavor also roast dominated, with a little caramel sweetness.

Split a 22oz amongst friends. Poured a almost pitch black color, slight ruby notes when put up to the light, foamy tan head. Aroma was some roasted malts with an ice pine character, touch of citrus. Flavor was some pine needle character, with some chocolate, roasted malts. Overall this one was pretty good with alcohol very well masked for 11%!
Bomber->SA.  Black with huge frothy tan head.  Aroma: citrus hops, sweet malt.  Taste: pepper, pine hops, roasted malt and chocolate.  Interesting and good.
Bomber into glass...  pitch black pour.. aroma is hoppy pine jiy..taste is freaking awesome..love it

Bottle from mane liquor. Pours a jet black with a tanned head. Nose heavy on roasted malts and coffee with a touch of pine. Taste has some grapefruit about it. More coffee and roasted malt coming through. Huge hop bitterness smashes the palate at the backend. Feel the alcohol but certainly can't taste it! Pretty good beer! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle shared by oRos. Pours dark brown with a modest tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a dark molasses, chocolate and anise flavor with a bitter hoppy citrus finish. Complex and tasty.
Bottle from ledgers in berkeley. Taste is very malty to start. With a bitter hop finish. Pepper spices in the aftertaste.
Poured into glass from bomber... black color nice white head. Good hop notes. Good malt notes. Good balance.

651ml. bottle. 10 ABV per the label. Pours a medium well retained beige head, over a clear brown black (SRM 35) body......nose is coffee, chocolate, pine, resin, citrus peel.....taste is coffee, chocolate, pine, resin, hints of brown sugar or molasses, finishing with a moderate, lingering pine bitterness......mouth feel medium, alcohol heat present (not fusel), carbonation low. This is part of the new genre of a Black D/IIPA. The malt backbone in this beer falls into the heavily roasted category. A bit more caramel/crystal would give a greater depth of malt complexity. The hop backbone could use more crisp, assertive buttering. All that said this is good beer that could be made better. The change in ABV indicates a change in recipe. BJCP 8/3/15/4/7
Pours dark brown with a soapy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, pine, roasted malt, and citrus. Taste is fresh pine needles, chocolate nibs, cocoa, and a nice hop bitterness. Delicious.

Bomber from trade with Crajun.  Pours pitch black with a small bubbly head that fades normally, leaves a little webbing.  Very nice aroma of chocolate, pine, grapefruit, wet grass, medium roast, cocoa, and dark fruit.  Taste is a nice balance of dark malts and hops.  Dark roast and chocolate balanced with dank pine, citrus, and grassy hops.  Finish is smooth and long, dark roasted malt taste lingers.  Medium body.  Oily and slightly chalky mouthfeel.  Overall, a very good Black DIPA but I recommend drinking fast.  Alcohol taste starts showing up as it warms.

22 oz. bomber. Cool to see these guys showing up in Cali! This one pours a very dark brown with a nice creamy tan head. The aroma is really nice with pine, cocoa, peaches, fresh turned soil, and a little brown sugar. The pine and peachy hops come through strong and balance nicely with the chocolate. The flavor is the same. Intense piney hop with a bit of dank, sweet peaches, caramel and earthy roast near the finish. Very bitter piney finish. The alcohol is very well hidden. Great beer.
bottle thanks homer!. pours black with medium off khaki head. aroma of roasted malt and hops. taste is very grassy and citrus, also lots of roasted malt and chocolate.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, thick black pour with nice fluffy tan head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, roast, nice grapefruit, orange, hints of slight dank pine, grassy notes, with a hint of lemon.  Taste is a mix of lots of coffee, dark chocolate, roast, some slight hints ofgrass, pine, dark fruits in there going into orange peel, touch of graperuit, slight earth, finishing fairly bitter.  Pretty well done, much better than the nonimperial version.
A bit of an older bottle, smells liek torpical fruit and an orange cocoa bar. Flaovr is all over the place with fruitiness and cocoa roastiness. Example of too much going on.
22oz Bottle pours an intensely black color with a frothy head that dissipates quickly. Roasted malt flavors and some hoppy bitterness balanced out to make the 10% alcohol unnoticeable.

9/IV/13 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle from De Hopduvel (Gent) @ home - BB: n/a (2013-321) Thanks to Dimi for sharing the bottle! 
Clear very dark brown beer, nice irregular beige head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: lots of citrus, some exotic fruits, bubble gum, bit sweet, cola candy bottles. MF: ok carbon, full body. Taste: very fruity, citrus, pretty bitter, pineapple, passion fruits, bit sweet, caramel. Aftertaste: still fruity, citrus, bit sourish, passion fruits, pineapple, caramel, piny hops. Really good beer!
Bomber shared during the Super Bowl.  Underwhelmed with this Black IPA due to its meldy soapy nature

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, floral/pine hops, caramel, & citrus; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, dark chocolate, pine hops, some coffee, and citrus; Finish is fairly bitter; Nicely balanced; Very good.

A pretty good brew with head around the ring.  Dark dark.  nice hop flavor and aroma.   A bit bitter but good balance with the dark Nice brew.  Enjoable.  Hoppy... only to a hop head?  they are very Hoppy.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bomber. Oh my goodness, this is terrific! Super dark pour with a frothy tan head. Full slick palate with nice carbonation. Lots of pine hop, roasty malts, chocolate....quite complex and in a way that is highly complementary. Fantastic beer.
Great. Black with tan head. Aroma is pine and a little pine. Taste is pine and bitter pine. Did I mention pine? Nice.
22oz bomber. Pours a deep black with a nice frothy mocha head. Aroma of piney and earthy hops with a nice roastiness. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, with piney hop bitterness.

Pours dark as stout, with a beige head. The aroma is hoppy, really hoppy, citrus, grapefruit rind, resin, and pine. The flavour is a little more complex though, still hoppy, big on the grapefruit and pine, some medical notes, saltiness, maybe a bit of chocolate then it trails off on a sort of caraway note thats tied in with a bit of astringent mouthfeel, its weird, but I like it.

65cl, at 10%Vol, as Hoppy Feet 1.5, new American brew Anno 2011, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex bitter brew, malty/roasted and slightly fruity/woody, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!
From notes.  Had this when it was fairly fresh in spring 2012.  Nice hoppy aroma, with a malty finish.  Solid Black IPA.  needs to be brewed again and go into rotation.

Bomber from Greens in Atlanta.  Ink black pour with a thin light brown head.  Aroma is roasty, smoky, coffee and grapefruit.  Tastes are roasted coffee, dark fruit, black cherry, and chocolate.  Nice silky texture.  Very impressed.

Bottle @ Beer Temple, Amsterdam.
Pours like motor oil, so thick and dark, with almost no head.
Nose has liquorice and burnt sugar and slight hop.
Lovely rich, full taste, with only modest sweetness in the beginning. Herby notes and liquorice in middle with nicely soothing bitter aftertaste.
Very nice indeed.

22oz bottle thanks to demmbonz 
Appearance: Pours black with a big frothy tan head and lots of sticky lacing 
Aroma: Citrus and pine resin 
Taste: Roasty, sweet caramel, rich chocolate, citrus, finishes with bitter pine resin 
Wow, I could drink this every night. Well balanced and hoppy. This is 10%, I wouldnt have guessed that if it wasnt on the bottle. Nice.
Pours near black with very small tan head and little lacing.  Aroma of pine hops and pepper.  Taste is pine and citrus hops and carmel malts with bitter coffee aftertaste. Full-bodied, powerful beer.
Solid black ipa offering. Lots of hops flavor and aroma that is balanced out with a good amount of toasted malt. Some bittersweet chocolate and citrus. Finish is slightly bitter and dry. Good stuff

22oz bottle.  Bottled on 02/2012.  Dark brown pour, light brown head.  Aroma of hops.  Scents of citrus and pine hops.  Not much malt, I expected there to be a touch of roasted barley.  Just hops and a good amount of booze.  Tastes of some coffee/burnt grains, loads of hops.  Bitterness lingers all through out the finish.  Sharp pine bite from hops.  Bitter citrus rind as well.  Overall, its kinda what I expected out of this First Anniversary brew.  

(3643)

27th May 2012Opaque black beer. Good pale tan head. Palate is smooth and a little dry. Crispy. Slightly roasty dark malt, a little salty. Strong pine hops,  bitter. Trace of red berry fruits. Smooth semi dry finish. Manages to be both smooth and harsh at the same time.

Botted. Pitch black beer, thick beige head. Strong resiny-citrusy hops with floral Amerillo notes. Dry, slightly spicy/rye-like sour malt aromas, some medicinal salty licorice notes. A hint of dark chocolate. Hammering resiny bitterness, some sweetly grassy/herbal notes. Sweeter fruitines is marginal. Firm malty body, but it get overrun by bitterness. Bone dry, resiny bitter finish. Medium to full body. Great beer but it needs more depth to be a true Masterpiece.

Pours dark, black as night with a thick pillowy brown head.  Nose is big pine, grass, resin, hints of chocolate and coffee with a bit o smoke too.  The taste is perfect balanced bittersweet ultimately giving way to a more bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is creamy, yet has crispness to it as well.  The body is heavy and the finish is long.
Nice brew. Puss dark brown with tan head. Aroma is piney hops and dark chocolate malts. Medium bodied and smooth. Finishes with a slight hop bite.

22 oz bottle - pours dark brown-black, with medium tan head, decent lacing. Big hoppy aromas of pine, resin, citrus notes, biscuit and cookie notes well-woven into the mix. Touch of chocolate. Tastes roasty malty, dark bread, citrus and hops, finishing with malty bitter backbone. Well-balanced and pretty tasty.

January 26, 2013 - bottle from AV1.  Black pour with lots of head and some lacing.  Little bit of foam sat around for a while.  Aroma was piney hops, roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste was consistent with a piney bitter finish and some noticeable alcohol.

Bottle shared by a friend. The beer pours nearly black with a medium foamy tan head that dissipates steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of hops, pine and roasted malt. Full-bodied with flavors of resiny hops, roasted malt and a touch of chocolate. The finish is moderately bitter with a lingering hoppy aftertaste. Solid Black IPA overall.
Bottle at Beertemple, Amsterdam. Black with a steady beige head. Roasted citrus nose. Good bitter caramel citrus and coffee flavours. Nice.

Bottle. Black with a smal light brown head that leaves lacing. Aroma is sweet roast, chocolate, pine, resin, citrus. Taste is medium/heavy sweet, later heavy bitter, full body, oily texture, soft/medum carbonation. Long dry heavy bitter hop finish with pine and a bit of citrus. Massive black ipa with dominating hops which is some achievement considering the malt body and abv.

650ml bottle from Archive. Looks like a stout, smells like an IPA. Black as the depths of space with a coffee coloured foam. Nose filling hop aromas are present and very good. Chocolate, vanilla and some aniseed in the flavour, which hits you right in the back of the throat and you get a slight alcohol burn that stays around. Rich creamy velvet mouthfeel. A great label on the bottle accompanies this great beer.

Dark brown with a large beige fluffy protector.  Aroma of dark malts, chocolate, citrus, licorice and mild grains.  Taste of chocolate, citrus, orange, dark malts, alcohol and a moderate hoppy finish.

Bomber courtesy of Strykzone.  Pours near black with a foamy tan head and a lot of lacing .Nose of chocolate malts and pine hops. Medium to heavy body. Creamy mouthfeel with alcohol showing a little. Flavor is roasted chocolate malt and a big dose of citrus and pine hops. Bitter finish.  Lots of flavor here. Very good

22oz bottle, bottled 8/28/12. Thanks to cbkschubert for getting me this. Very dark brown pour. Nice light clear brown head. Decent lace. Good big pine and earthy herbal hop aroma. Not too big of a body. Some chocolate in the nose. Nice bitter taste, some light sweetness. Alcohol is well-hidden by the excellent flavor. Some chocolate, good roasty malts, but mostly just that good huge herbal earthy piney hop flavor. Light alcohol bite in the finish, light smoke in the nose. I really enjoy a good Black IPA..
Pours dark with tan head and slight lace. Aroma is caramel, chocolate,citrus. Taste dark bitter coffee, sweet malts, dark chocolate. Lots of hop bitterness, sticky long finish

Black oily beer with a foamy, rich tan head. The aroma is sharp and bitter with alcohol. The taste is roasted malt, a lot of bitterness from heavy hopping and alcohol. These are characteristics i usually shun, but somehow this beer is really good. The malty sweetness somehow balances it all out. Another top notch beer from Clown Shoes. These guys have figured out something.

Pours pretty much an almost black with a creamy/bubbly tan head that left sticky lacing.  Aroma of orange peel, other citrusy hop notes and a touch of caramel malt.  Flavor of lightly roasted malt and toasted caramel salted caramel with pretzel bites.  Some citrusy and piney notes.  Hops dominate the nose while the malt bill comes through a bit in the flavor more.

Deep brown with reddish hue. Bit I a tan head. Hop aroma has faded here a little bit and gettin more of a roasty malt aspect with some faint grassiness. Flavor is full bodied and the alcohol is hidden well. Burned wood some cherry flavors and a bittersweet coffee flavor. Finish is peppery bitter and nice. Interesting beer and pretty tasty.

black color, aroma of piney/citrus hops, dark chocolate, roasted malt, flavors of pine funky spicy hops, roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, med body, nice roasty bitter finish, cant taste the booze at all, very good

Wow.  This really is a big beer.  Everything about it is big and in your face.  Not much subtlety here.  Pours a deep burgundy reddish black.  Aroma is a ton of very fresh hops, followed by licorice and dried cherry.  More dried cherry in the first sip, then fades into a grassy pine bitterness, with cocoa powder and dark chocolate to round it out.  No way you can pick up that this is 11% abv, too well hidden.  Usually not a big fan of big/extreme beers due to lack of balance, but for some reason this kind of all works together in its own big way....

Bomber.  Poured deep brown with a well-retained, sticky cap of dark beige head.  The aroma picked up near-burnt black and licorice malts with bright pine and peppery alcohol accents.. came across strong, but not 11% strong.  The flavor opened with pine and citrus bitterness plus peppery alcohol.. burnt black patent and toasted chocolate malts followed.. heavy pine and grapefruit bitterness and peppery alcohol over cocoa and dark fruit on the long, warm, kind of burnt finish.  Medium-plus bodied and very bitter on the palate.. carbonation kept it moving along.. just too big and muddled in the end.

Bottle (65 cl) from bierkompass.de. Deep brown, medium beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma with piney, citric, and perfumy hops. Medium to full bodied, medium carbonation. Semi dry with medium bitterness.

Pours an inky dark brown with an off white head.  Aroma of raisins, slight smokiness and malt.  Taste is coffee, smoke, with a coffee type bitterness on a creamy smooth mouthfeel with little alcohol presence coming through.
Det här är en riktigt bra öl med en skön balans och en stabil kropp. Smaken är komplex och bär toner av choklad, fruktighet och lite kaffe. Slutsats: en riktigt god öl och rolig öl-upplevelse.

650ml bottle. Black with plenty of light brown head. Nice piney and fruity aroma. The taste joins smooth roasted malt tones with occasional light smokey hints. Hops have probably faded quite drastically but they still impart a good presence on the tongue. Fairly thick, well-balanced mouthfeel and mildly bitter as it ends. Dont think Id put this in the highest tier but a fresher one might get close.

Bottle. Pours a very black color with a moderate off-white head. The nose is fairly hoppy, foreshadowing some bitterness; however, underneath the hops are some sweeter malts, which makes for an interesting mix. Taste isnt too bitter, as the sweeter malt notes balance them out.

Deep and dark like a porter with a foamy tan head. Slightly roasty malt, smooth with hints of toast and coffee, then a nice, but smooth, punch of hops in the end. The alcohol content is well hidden. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours near-inky black, big latte-colored head. Nose is dominated up front by the roasted malts, with only residual pine hoppiness in the background. Big punch of bitter on the first sip, then easing into the roastiness once more, hint of bakers chocolate. Finish is somewhere between burnt and astringent. Well done.

Ugh this didnt save my rating so Im just going from memory. Pitch black, oily like a stout. Some smoky burnt coffee but some grapefruity hops too. Tastes of strong resiny hops with roasted malt backing. Really nice and the abv is totally hidden.
Bottle. Pours black with a little cream colored head. Aroma is roasted malts and bitter hops. Flavor is strong roasted malts, chocolate, and bitter hops.

Sampled @ Beer Temple. Pitch black color, medium sized light brown head. Smell malts, hops, roastyness, chocolate, some citrus, grapefruit, and lightly alcohol. Taste sweetness and bitterness, malts, roastyness, a hint of chocolate, citrus, grapefruit. Oily texture, medium to full body, medium carbonation.

From Hophead, DK.
Bottled, 181012.
Black with white head. Aroma of chocolate and spices. Flavour with roasts, coffee and fruit.
From a 22 oz bottle shared at home  Pours almost black with big frothy head.  Hop and raisin nose.   Hints of black cherries with a massive hop finish.

Tap. Pours clear deep black red with a small beige head and decent lacing. Aroma is caramel and coffee dominated, with notes of dark roasted malt, citrus, grapefruit, and pine. Flavor is the same, medium sweet with a medium bitter finish, staying strong into the far finish. A bit of warming on the finish, but the ABV hidden well otherwise. Medium body.

Solid, interesting double black IPA. Aroma is moderate, with toasty notes not unlike a stout and some mild bitterness. Flavor is complex, with mild hops, toastiness; a great balance. Long, warming finish. Somewhat creamy in consistency. (10/18/12 @Total Wine IPA tasting class w/Tony.)

Has some big chocolate and dark fruit notes, almost like an imperial stout. Has  a great bitter flavor and super smooth body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark pour  thick tan head great lacing.  Warm alcohol on the nose a fair amount of roast malt along with a good amount of bitterness acids.  Full well coated palate.  Lightly sweet toffees hints of caramel orange zest light grass in the finish.  Very drinkable.

When I started tasting this (right out of the refrigerator), it was a pretty stout, dark chocolate with a few high notes in the aroma.  As it warmed though, it opened up really well.  The initial dark chocolate malt turns into a pleasant blend of spice, bitter, and floral notes.  There is a lot of hop character, but the bitterness doesnt overpower.

Bottle: August, 2012. Pours pitch black with a creamy mocha head. Nose is roasted coffee, dark chocolate bar with fruit and nuts, peanuts, tropical fruit, pine. Taste is dark chocolate, juicy tropical fruits, pine, hop oils, and bitter coffee. The alcohol is masked very well.

22oz Bottle. The pour was a deep dark pitch black with an average (1-2 finger) light brown foamy head that had great retention lasting pretty much throughout and produced excellent sheets of lacing that totally coated the glass.

The aroma was of a roasted sweet bread malt, pine and citrus hops and a bitter leathery yeast with notes of chocolate, coffee, citrus (grapefruit) and a touch of dark fruit (berries).

The taste started somewhat sweet and malty with notes of chocolate and coffee, and then had an influx of dark fruit with a bitter hoppy citrus peel ending. The flavor lingered for an extended period of time with a smooth, hoppy, chocolate bitterness left to settle on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was almost medium in body with a very dry texture and a rather soft carbonation.

Overall this brew was smooth, creamy and a tad hoppy with a great chocolate feel and a mild fruity sweetness, which hid the high ABV completely. All that and a great drinkability, yes I think I will have another...

Bottle 22fl.oz.ABV: 10.0%. Clear dark red brown colour with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, moderate to heavy hoppy, citrus, grapefruit, orange - citrus, light alcohol. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long long duration, roasted - chocolate, citrus - grapefruit, bitter bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel light to light moderate alcoholic. [20120817]
Pours inky black. A strong bitter chocolate aroma which dominates the hop aroma. Flavour is a good balance of the two

Bottle from Total Wine.  very nice black IPA, cola color, very little head or lacing, nice hop charcoal fragrance and taste to match.  Plenty of ops and peat, acidic probably from a igh carbonation level.
Bottle pour. Black with a tan head that really sticks around. Roasted malt character with really nice hoppiness - I really like the complexity of this beer, a bit boozy on the finish in a good way!

Very nice beer. Pours a thick, dark black with massive head that grows and grows (keeps spilling over the lip of my glass, actually). Aroma has hints of chocolate and licorice. Flavor is quite complex: sweet, spicy, almost peppery at first taste. Big licorice, some malt sweetness, hop/citrus bite, toasty grain. Very smooth finish. A keeper.

Really solid Black IPA...almost Escondidian!  In all seriousness, this is a damn fine example of the style.  Chocolate pour, but more citrus and hop bite than malts everywhere else.  Candied orange slices, lemon peel, grapefruit, and evergreen.  Medium mouthfeel.  Yum!

(Bottle) Pours dark brown to black with a pale brown head.  The aroma holds nutty, dry caramelly, earthy, salt liquorice-like, dark bready and asphalt roasted malt alongside hoppy notes of grapefruit, blood orange, resin, wood, pine, tart yellow fruits, unripe berries, juniper and grass. Undertones of cucumber, aromatic dried pepper, green pepper, wet tobacco, blueberries, mint, wet stones/minerals and jalapeno oil. Robust malt/roast and stick hops. The flavour is light sweet, medium to heavily bitter and light to medium acidic with notes of grapefruit, blood oranges, resinous wood, bitter grass, bitter herbs, tart berries/fruits, liquorice, dry roast, coffee, dark berries. and alcohol. The mouthfeel is round, creamy, and soft with a light carbonation. Aggressive resinous and roasted finish. Medium bodied.

A delicious double black IPA.  A real treat. Toasted malt and creamy hops create a rich toasty and buttery flavor. One of the best black IPAs.  Pours stout black with a thick frothy head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Love this. They nailed it. The piney aftertaste and bitterness mixes well with sweet chocolate-like malt base. Mouthfeel has a webby texture to accentuate the flavors. Both dark malt and citrus in the aroma.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours dark, dark brown with a large, dense tan head. Lovely lacing left about. Nose is quite ashy with lots of powdery dark chocolate, almost cacao like. Roasted malts and caramel behind it all. Gives off a hint of the bitterness which is about to come. Loads of piney hops and heavy cocoa powder in the taste. Very bitter without being too much. Good, lengthy stuff. A little over carbonated but works fine. Very nice

Pours Black as midnight with a nice foamy tan head. Smells of chocolate and roasted malts with a hint of caramel malts and some floral hops.  Taste the roasted and citrus malts throughout with lots of pine and resin hops. There is a very subtle sweetness of caramel and fruit. Distinct Chocolate flavor.  Dry bitter finish. Delish!

650ml bottle. Pitch black colour with average, frothy, minimally lacing, off-white head. Dark malty, roasty aroma with decent notes of liquorice, intense grassy hop overtones, a touch of citrus. Taste is peppery with notes of green onions, roasty dark malty, dry, grassy hoppy. Well balanced, well hidden alcohol.

Appearance: Pours out a dark color that I can only describe as black. It has a tight 2 finger khaki, chocolate milk colored head that sticks around for a surprisingly long time. Moderate lacing on this one. A nice looking black IPA.

Smell: Whew this is an interesting smelling beer. I was expecting much more hops on the nose but instead I get tons of dark malts. Im picking up toasted characteristics with nutty and biscuit, too. Some mild faint coffee in there also. Then and only then do I get some piney hops on the back end. This smell reminds me much more of a roasty stout than an IPA.

Taste: Oh my, a nice initial taste on this with the roasted coffee, chocolate, and sweetness. This is followed up by a great hop profile of pine hops and bitterness that prickles the taste buds and sticks around for a long time after the swallow. The alcohol at 11% is so well hidden behind all this goodness that it is almost non existent.

Mouthfeel: I think the feel on this beer is spot on for the style. It is medium with moderate carbonation and a creamy feel in the mouth. 

Overall: This to me is the best of both worlds in that it is combining a stout and an IPA. I love the melding of flavors in the two styles and the end result is very enjoyable. A sipping beer for me but dangerously so because of the alcohol being so well disguised. I like this beer!

Bottle split with Pat, pours a dark black, with medium laving and a nice mocha color head. Aromas of chocolate, peanut butter cookie, citrus hops, dark and roasty malts, and milk. Taste is velvety smooth for a black IPA with sugar notes, bitter cocoa, full flavored hops with a decent bite to them on the finish. Other notes we found were sticky mollases. My first beer from Clown Shoes did not disappoint.

opaque black with a thick tan head. Full body with high carbonation.

Aroma: grassy citrusy hops, black roasted barley, and some toffee sweetness.

Taste: Heavy roasted barley and chocolate malt, grassy citrusy hops, and some alcohol.
Bottled sample. Great beer. Bit sweeter than I would have liked. Chocolate really shines through

Thanks to CaSSino for this bottle!

Poured from a bomber into a snifter

A.  Pours a deep dark black, heavy foam head from an aggressive pour, about 2 fingers thick, after settling, it retained a nice 1mm head with very nice lacing

S.  Smells of sweet fruit, cascade hops, sweet pine and a little bit of maple

T.  Sweet maple, very malty with a lot of tangy hops.  Lots and lots of hops.  If you have ever complained of not enough hops in your BIPA, this is the beer for you!  

M.  Medium body, thick and chewy with a very dry and coarse finish

O.  Quality beer.  Great overall, very hoppy and with well balanced flavors.  Just a great overall beer.  This is one I could drink on a regular basis.  Im sad that we had this towards the end of the night because I really could not drink a lot of it, but it deserves much more.
Pours black with a small tan head. By the description, I was expecting a lot more hops. Instead I got a lot of fruit, prunes mostly and some chocolate. Full bodied, sweet and thick.
Very nice dark pour with a thin head. Thick roasted malts. Hops. Semi-sweet. For me, this is one of the best dark doubles out there.
A super roasty, 4C styled IPA.  Rather bitter, harsh flavor balance, all-around solid in a style that I dont love.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2017 I wasnt a fan of this beer. It seemed unbalanced and had a medicinal aroma and flavor.  A lot of hops and some anise flavor. Serving: Bottle
black pour with a khaki head.  nose is chocolate, citrus, graham cracker, and cocoa.  thick on the palate, heavy roasted malts, chocolate, and a smooth citrus kick in the finish.

bottle Hoppy Monk El Paso, TX-pours black with a small soapy tan head.  Lightly oxidized metallic nose with lots of bitters and char, roast with huge burnt notes.  hugely roasty flavors with char on the finish.  Hops are there ,but not as birght as i was expecting them to be.  This seems more like an imperial stout with some hops added not a black IIPA.  With that said, this is a very tasty beer and it will mess you up!  As it warmed, the metallic notes faided away showing the very robust malt presence of nutty roast, char and dark choclate with leafy, bitter piney hops.  balanced beer?  no.  HOwever, this is a pretty bold and powerful beer that I thought was pretty well done.

Bottle (mine labeled at 10% ABV). Pours with a near black body with a large, fluffy brown head. Aromas are of perfume, sweet, brown sugar, canned pineapple, earthy with some fudge. Flavors are bitter, nutty, fudge. Astringently bitter (from the roast) and decently bitter from the hops. Bready, medium sweet. A bit messy. Lively carbonation, medium bubbles, lasting astringency.

Pours an opaque coffee brown with a fairly thick light tan head that leaves some good lacing. Aroma has a strong burnt hops note, an earthy tone, and hints of licorice and roast malt. Flavor is hoppy and smoky, only a little bitter, with hints of licorice, malt and caramel. Lively texture has slightly above-average body and leaves a nice smoky, woody, slightly sweet and slightly bitter finish.

Bomber. Black with a tan head. Malty chocolate nose. Taste is a bit harsh with some chocolate notes and a malty smooth body. Alcohol is upfront and harsh. Not bad but the alcohol bite detracts from the taste.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Like Hoppy Feet but more powerful and more of everything.  Hides the alcohol well - no idea it was 11% until reading here.

Dark brown body was mostly opaque, and the head atop was quite large at three to four fingers thick.  While it looked like a stout, it certainly did not smell like one.  The hops were very noticeable in the piney and earthy smell.  There was a touch of chocolate at the end of each whiff, betraying the presence of dark malts.  The taste was perfectly straddling the line between a stout and a DIPA.  The hops were clearly there in the bitterness up front, which was followed by a different, more astringent bitterness from the roasting of the grains.  There was also a small amount of sweetness that alternated between molasses and rock candy.  The aftertaste was very bitter, and lingered long after the beer had already passed the throat.  Very silky mouthfeel with no harshness.  Phenomenal beer from a brewery whose products are newly being distributed around here.  I will be back for more of your beers very soon.

Tap at 4th Avenue Pub last night with Erica. Poured jet black and left a thick (but inconsistent) lacing on the inside of the chalice it was served in. Aroma was very sweet and chocolatey, and so was the flavor. Heavy milk chocolate and not a ton of roastiness, which is a welcome break from the norm in the style. I thought of Nesquick right off the bat. Very good.

sorry, were out- no, youre not .. . Pours a deep black .. good good foam .. . roast, burnt aspirin, tar, ash, and burnt penguin .. . decent mouth, hides the abv well but lacks any depth .. . . That raccoon stole my lamb chop!

22oz bottle: pours a barely transparent blackish mahogany with a spotty-lacing froth of beige head. Has a fresh resiny hop nose and good dark malty sweetness with a touch of mild roast.  Starts with good fullness and chewy sweet dark caramel malts with lots of citrusy hop flavor and bitter balance before a drier bittersweet finish. True to style and dangerously drinkable.
Bottle.  Pours a dartk black with a nose of coffee, chocolate, and raspberry chocolate.  Flavor follows suit.  Nice coffee beer but not otherwise.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Courtesy of ksurkin. Bomber pours dark dark mahogany with tan head and a bit of lacing left behind on the glass. The modest aroma offers up a mix of orange juice, grapefruit and bitter pine hoppiness as well as roasty malts, burnt malts and a sort of earthy chocolate. The taste is expectedly bold on all fronts with vibrant bitter pine hops rolling into some grapefruit and tangelo. Then it seems big roasted to chocolate to burnt malts dominate with the hoppy notes just hanging around the edges. Good drinkin bold brew where I get almost no sense of the big ABV.

Aroma is citrus, grapefruit with chocolate and a bit of alcohol.  The taste is almost completely void of the 11%.  Its a smooth combo of pine and citrus hops, chocolate, roasted malts and a hint of ripe dark fruits.  The lingering bitterness is quite nice.  This is the biggest black ipa Ive had to date and my first clown shoes brew.  Digging this one.

Pours black with a creamy light brown head that laces a little bit. Aroma of citrusy grapefruit hops and some malty roast. Rich, sticky mouth feel of roasty malts, some cocoa, and piney herbal hops. Finishes pretty bitter. Alcohol is very well hidden.

Growler from my local Whole Foods. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of sweet citrus, grapefruit, and chocolate. Flavor of chocolate , dark fruits, roasted malt, citrusy hops. Not as hoppy as its counterpart, hoppy feet, with more dark fruits and malt. Great beer, cant believe this one is 11%! It certainly does not come off as boozy nor even sweet although one pint of it does set you back a little. Impressed, as always, by Clown Shoes.
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)
The look is black, has a tan head and dark.  The smell is hoppy, roast, citrus, and pine trees.  You can almost chew the hops, a real mix of hops and roast in the taste.  Lasting bitterness.

Pine needle, charred oak, peanut hulls, and freshly cut oak aroma, rustic and woody. Dark mahogany, medium beige head, uniform glass coating. Flavor is as much split wood as anything but charred oak, chocolate,  and licorice notes come and go and are more prominent upon warming. There is a consistent yet vague bitterness from start to finish. This bitterness is a little too much, but thats my sole nit pick. My guess is that it comes more from the black malt than any hopping. Stone Sublimely is still the undisputed champion but I really like this. This is a session beer for imperial stout fans. Greg, keep these fine beers coming.

22oz bottle.  almost black with a large, fluffy, tan head.  citrus hops and cocoa nose.  surprisingly the chocolate malt wins the battle here with a nice cocoa flavor that almost mellows the hop bite.  occasional coffee notes.  pot brownies.  a really smooth BIPA for the size of it.  i would never guess the abv.  one of the few impressive black ipas.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color. Very dark indeed. Tan colored head. Aroma is dark chocolate, celery and hops. Flavor is dry hops, roasted malts and a light bitter finish. Not bad despite the veggie smell.
22 oz bottle.....Solid brew. Pours black with tan head. Notes of strong dark roasted grain with big piny hop profile and bitter chocolate. Mouthfeel is heavy body with medium-high carbonation.

22 oz bottle via trade. Poured a good looking pitch black body underneath a huge foamy light beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate, grapefruit, dark toast, oranges, dark fruit and citrus rinds. Fuler chewy body with average tight carbonaton and a lingering bitter bite on the end. Flavor is much like the aroma and loaded with burnt malts, darker chocolate, lots of citrus rind, grapefruit and some dark fruit. This is good stuff and no hint of the ridiculous 11% ABV, well at least until you stand up.
Not a lot in the aroma; looks great though. This is pretty tasty. Definitely roasty, but lots of hops. Actually smoother than the original. Seems more like a 7 or 8% beer.

bottle at Pizza Plant. Strong brew. Dark black pour. Roasty, boozy & piney hop aroma. Hops were very prevelent in the aroma. Strong flavor of the aforementioned aroma, big piney bitterness, boozy, good amount of roasted malts. pretty extreme but it all seemed to work pretty well. Nice

22oz bottle.
I wasnt too impressed with the regular Hoppy Feet and decided to give this a try.  I did enjoy this more than the non 1.5 version but I tend to like my beers big and complex.  Deep black pour with a sticky tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, roast, dank pine hops, and some graham cracker.  Flavor is a nice mix of roasted malt, chocolate, and hop punch.

Im not usually a fan of this style but this was a very good beer. Aroma was big and hoppy. Strong mix of citrus, grapefruit hops and a slight roasted malt note. Pour was a nice deep dark brown with a thin near tan ring for a head. Taste was very deceptive. This does not taste like an 11% beer. Full of flavor. Strong grapefruit and piney hops from start to finish with a subtle hint of roasted malt weaving in and out. A little chocolate comes out as it warms but doesnt distract from the heavy bitter hop flavor. Finish is extremely bitter and hoppy. Strong carbonation. Great beer
